content:
I've just got one little step before Lemma 7.3.2 is sorry-free ‚Äì in the second case, why is smul 6 p'' ‚â§ smul 6 p'?

Will surely welcome solutions over the weekend when @Floris van Doorn isn't around.

Here is what I have so far
20250308_121638.jpg

If ùìò p'' ‚â† ùìò p' then I can prove it; based on the diagram smul 6 p'' ‚â§ smul 1 p', from which smul 7 p'' ‚â§ smul 7 p' can be deduced (the increase from 6 to 7 can definitely be accommodated).

If p'' = p' then the conclusion is obvious.

But if p'' ‚â† p' and ùìò p'' = ùìò p' ‚Äì from which follows that Disjoint (Œ© p'') (Œ© p') ‚Äì I have two balls of the same radius in the same metric but different centres and I don't know what to do. I also can't prove that this case is impossible.
How is this third case impossible, or do I need a p'' with more properties?
I looked at the problem yesterday, and didn't see what to do in the third case quickly, so I asked Lars for help, but didn't get a response yet.

Here is the response from Lars

Yes, that seems to be a problem.
One fix is to distinguish case, when I(p'') = L' one defines p' = p''
instead of defining it as in the current version of the proof. Then L \cap
E(q) is still contained in E_2(n, p''), with possibly a constant n a
little bit larger than 6. This follows from similar arguments as in the
other case, using that now B_u(Q(u),1) is contained in B_p'(Q(p'), 4)
instead of that \Omega(u) and \Omega(p') intersect.
I will change this in the blueprint later.
Armed with Lars's comment I've finished and pushed the proof of Lemma 7.3.2, am now polishing it up before I declare it ready
Jeremy Tan has marked this topic as resolved.
